title: 106_s3196
content: The Act is named the "George E. Brown, Jr. Hydrogen Future Act" and aims to amend a previous Act regarding hydrogen research. It includes a report to Congress. SEC. 3. REPORT TO CONGRESS. Amends the Spark M. Matsunaga Hydrogen Research, Development, and Demonstration Act of 1990 by updating deadlines and requirements for a report to Congress on hydrogen-related activities. Includes analysis for increased collaboration and coordination plan with other Federal agencies. Also, includes State and local activities in the report. Section 106 of the Spark M. Matsunaga Hydrogen Research, Development, and Demonstration Act of 1990 is amended to include an update of the inventory and involve other Federal agencies in the information exchange program through workshops, publications, conferences, and a database for public and private sectors. The Spark M. Matsunaga Hydrogen Research, Development, and Demonstration Act of 1990 is amended to involve other Federal agencies in an information exchange program through workshops, publications, conferences, and a database for public and private sectors to foster the exchange of nonproprietary information and technology among industry, academia, and the Federal Government. SEC. 5. TECHNICAL PANEL REVIEW. Amendment to the Spark M. Matsunaga Hydrogen Research, Development, and Demonstration Act of 1990 to include a plan developed by the interagency task force under the Hydrogen Future Act of 1996. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Amends Section 109 of the Spark M. Matsunaga Hydrogen Research, Development, and Demonstration Act of 1990 to allocate funding for fiscal years 2002 to 2006. SEC. 7. FUEL CELLS. SEC. 7. FUEL CELLS. Amends the Hydrogen Future Act of 1996 to integrate fuel cells with hydrogen production systems and establish an interagency task force for technical information sharing. The Secretary will establish an interagency task force within 120 days of this section's enactment, led by a Deputy Assistant Secretary of Energy and including representatives from various government agencies. The task force will develop a plan focusing on the development and demonstration of integrated systems and components for carrying out the title. The plan will focus on demonstrating integrated systems and components for hydrogen production, storage, and use in Federal buildings, power generation, and transportation systems. It may include projects for hydrogen-based distributed power systems, combined heat and power generation, and infrastructure for zero-emission vehicles. The Secretary will establish cooperative agreements with Federal and State agencies to replace fossil fuel systems with fuel cell systems. Additionally, technical information will be integrated. The Secretary will integrate technical information from development projects and make it available to Federal and State agencies. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2002-2004 is set at $50,000,000.
